Researchers deployed AI bots to Reddit’s r/ChangeMyView to see if they could sway human opinions, without Reddit’s knowledge. Linus and Luke dive into how this unauthorized experiment touched on sensitive topics, profiled users, and may now lead to legal action. They also discuss how AI's behaviour is changing, what it really remembers, and why blindly trusting chatbots is becoming a serious problem.

Watch the full WAN Show: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=MI7crSCITts

title: Reddit is suing them, and they deserve it

After a tragic death tied to chatbot interactions, Character.ai claims its bots’ output should be protected as free speech. Linus and Luke explore the murky legal future of AI liability, from dangerous chatbot advice to algorithmic misinformation in politics, and question whether society is ready for the consequences of letting AI into such intimate spaces.

Watch the full WAN Show: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=MI7crSCITts

Apple is in serious trouble. A federal judge has found the company and at least one senior executive in willful violation of a 2021 injunction from the Apple vs Epic Games case. The ruling accuses Apple of obstructing competition and lying under oath, with criminal prosecution now a real possibility. Linus and Luke break down the consequences, the internal Slack messages, and how this might finally open up the App Store for developers and users.

Watch the full WAN Show: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=MI7crSCITts

The U.S. just closed a massive import loophole, so if you’ve noticed higher prices on everything from Xboxes to LTT merch, you’re not imagining things. Linus and Luke break down how the removal of the de minimis tariff exemption is reshaping online shopping, exposing fast fashion’s hidden costs, and forcing LTTStore to split into two separate storefronts.

Watch the full WAN Show: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=MI7crSCITts
